Award.AwardTitle: RUI: Biodiversity Inventory: Gregarines Parasitizing North American Cockroaches
Award.AbstractNarration:
The project surveys and documents the biodiversity of North American cockroaches and their gregarine parasites. This is the first comprehensive survey of North American cockroaches since 1917 and the project will discover and describe 60-120 new parasite species. These parasites of insects, although closely related to the malarial parasites of humans, do not infect vertebrates. Of the 72 cockroach species known in North America, only 8 infest humans. The project discovers and documents cockroach and gregarine diversity through field survey, preparation of permanent museum collections, and the generation and analysis of morphological and molecular data. The project quantifies the effects of host species diversity and the environment on speciation using controlled studies of parasite development and experimental cross-infection of parasites among host species.

The project examines a basic question of biodiversity: what roles do host diversity and environmental conditions play in the formation and persistence of parasitic species? These questions underlie all biodiversity survey and their solution is key to understanding the formation and persistence of biodiversity as well as techniques for rapidly discovering and describing new species. Pragmatically, the project builds a specimen base to investigate and monitor the effects of climate change on biodiversity: cockroach distributions are delimited by climate but have not been surveyed in almost a century. The PI is in a small, rural, undergraduate institution. The project will train several undergraduate students who will likely choose to pursue careers in science as a direct result of their research experience.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project supported integrated faculty and undergraduate research at Peru State College (PSC) through a taxonomic survey and systematic analysis of gregarines (Protista: Apicomplexa) parasitizing the exotic and endemic cockroaches (Insecta: Dictyoptera) of North America north of Mexico. The project discovered and documented gregarine and cockroach biodiversity through expeditionary survey, screening, and culture of target host taxa to provide sufficient materials for gregarine description and host vouchering; empirical studies of gregarine host-specificity and phenotypic plasticity; and, undergraduate research training in taxonomy and systematics. The project tests hypotheses of speciation in hyperdiverse parasitic groups; develops a strategic model for gregarine taxonomy and a functional gregarine species concept to increase the speed and stability of future gregarine species discovery and description; and, provides critical early-career training to prepare young taxonomists for graduate study in systematic biology.

The project surveyed gregarine parasites (the most common trophic habit on Earth) in insects (the most prevalent and diverse metazoans on Earth). Thus the project focuses on an understudied group with profound scientific implications: the most common parasites of the planet’s most common animals. The project focuses on a survey of cockroaches and their gregarine parasites in North America.

The first general goal of the project was biological survey and inventory. To that end, the project made field collecting expeditions to Alabama, Florida Keys, Kansas, Louisiana (southern and western), Nebraska, North Carolina (Smoky Mountains), Oklahoma, Texas (Big Thicket), and the South Texas Scrubland. All undergraduate participants completed at least one expeditionary collecting trip and were trained in field collection, culturing, dissection, and processing techniques. We collected and cultured 37 cockroach species/strains and 22 putatively new gregarine species/strains; collected 18s-ITS-28s molecular data for 30 new and known putative gregarine species, and morphological data for 20 new and 9 known gregarine taxa across 4 genera infecting cockroaches; prepared over 1,500 new permanent gregarine specimens for deposition and loan through the University of Nebraska State Museum; and, prepared over 500 new permanent cockroach specimens for deposition and loan through the Natural History Collections of Sam Houston State University.

The second general goal of the project was to develop new techniques and resources for experimental studies of gregarine host and habitat specificity. To that end the project Illumina sequenced and annotated the first complete genome sequence for a gregarine in collaboration with Guan Zhu (Texas A&M). These data are being used to establish the relationship of Cryptosporidium and Eugregarinida relative to other major branches of Apicomplexa. We have used experimental cross-infections to determine the relative fitness of gregarines in normal and abnormal cockroach hosts and developed techniques for an excystation bioassay and evaluated gregarine excystation signals across 11 species of natural and unnatural cockroach hosts. These experiments provide valuable insight into mechanisms of gene-pool isolation and speciation in a hyperdiverse parasitic fauna. We also conducted studies of oocyst production and gregarine fecundity across 4 gregarine species and quantified the effects of temperature and humidity on the maturation and viability of gregarine oocysts over time. These experiments provide insight into the ecology of gregarine parasites as a simple epidemiological model for directly transmitted parasitic disease.
